It's an easy 3 step process
1: check the currents
2: put fishing + seaweed + shellfish floating cages in those currents
3: track them and when ready ships pick them up.

One thing I'm curious about on this topic - from the bits of studying I do, it seems earth just naturally goes through cycles of hot and cold and humans have only been around during a cold period - one that was already ending on its own although we've definitely sped up the warming part. Given that, I don't see how anyone could think that there is a way to 'stop' climate change, since the earth just naturally is going to warm up again regardless of our actions? Not saying we shouldn't strive for cleaner technology, but it seems a bit misguided to think that anything we do would have stopped the earth from following its natural cycle.

99% methane reduction is impossible: "feeding cattle algae is really only practical where it’s least needed: on feedlots. This is where most cattle are crowded in the final months of their 1.5- to 2-year lives to rapidly put on weight before slaughter. There, algae feed additives can be churned into the cows’ grain and soy feed. But on feedlots, cattle already belch less methane—only 11 percent of their lifetime output. That’s because most of their methane comes from their gut microbes breaking down the indigestible grass, leaves, and roughage they eat on the pastures beforehand, and not from feedlot corn and soy. This means that even if algae diets on feedlots worked perfectly, it wouldn’t help with the 89 percent of cows’ belches that occur earlier in their lives.

Unfortunately, adding the algae to diets on the pasture, where it’s most needed, isn’t a feasible option either. Out on grazing lands, it’s difficult to get cows to eat additives because they don’t like the taste of red algae unless it’s diluted into feed. And even if we did find ways to sneak algae in somehow, there’s a good chance their gut microbes would adapt and adjust, bringing their belches’ methane right back to high levels.

All told, if we accept the most promising claims of the algae boosters, we’re talking about an 80 percent reduction of methane among only 11 percent of all burps—roughly an 8.8 percent reduction total. Maybe a little more if we can work algae into cows’ diets on pastures. And that would only really count as a serious climate change mitigation strategy if we could find a way to change the diets of hundreds of millions of cows. This is not only a major logistical and economic challenge, it might also pose its own issues since we’d have to contend with the potential ecological impact of large-scale algae farming, be it in the wild or in aquaculture operations.

And there’s another problem. Although cow belches are the largest source of agricultural methane, beef and dairy production involve lots of other climate emissions, from their manure to the fertilizer sprayed on their crops and grasses, through to the transport of the animals and later the meat. While there may be technological solutions to all of these different emissions in a cow’s life cycle, algae is far from the silver bullet that can solve all of them.

It’s tempting to believe in quick technological fixes that will let us keep indulging in burgers without the climate guilt. That’s also why major beef producers and fast food chains are advertising it so heavily. But the fact is that currently, the only real solution available is to produce and eat less beef. According to leading experts in food and energy systems, we need to invest most of our efforts into solutions available to us today to stop greenhouse gas emissions from entering our atmosphere. As the World Wildlife Fund’s lead food scientist wrote last week, all of these solutions become easier to implement if we reduce our pressure on land and the climate by shifting toward more plant-based diets."

Carbon sequestration only happens if the plants remain as plants.  If you feed them to animals, you're putting that carbon back into the atmosphere.  Cows don't magically conjure methane; they're releasing the carbon of the plants they eat back into the atmosphere.

I'm wondering a few things though: seaweed is indeed great, but seaweed does also contain a ton of iodine in it. Wouldn't that eventually become a major problem? Common side effects of too much iodine can cause fever, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, burning sensations in throat and mouth and stomach pain.
Also, this is something I've noticed in every study that starts feeding cows other things besides grass: a cow isn't a herbivore, it's a grass eater. Seaweed isn't grass... They're highly specialised to eat grass. Other plants can be digested but I assume only in small amounts before, like with all animals, it becomes too much for them to digest.

I think it's time to seriously consider maybe to stop industrialising animals and crops all together. Farmers can still be there. Nothing needs to change in that regard, just instead of trying to feed states, countries and the world, just simply stop all this garbage and start making localised foods only. You can still get foods that aren't local, but they would cost way more. It will lower the imprint on the environment to a point where it's back in balance with what it used to be. What do we do with worldwide needs? Start looking into growing food in the lab. Give people an option: either get local food or lab grown food. Industrial food needs to go.

Methane Reduction, Electric fleets for farm equipment(which might be MORE efficient, power-transfer vehicles benefit from three phase electric motors because they require no gearing, they deliver their maximum torque at any RPM), and seaweed farms are all great, though I have some concerns about the seaweed farming and CO2. Ideally, if you want to cut down on CO2, you want to take it out of the system. Sequester it. Would it not be better to let the seaweed settle, perhaps even dumping it in the deep oceans? That way it feeds deep sea wildlife(if it sinks, that's a tricky part, it tends to float), and also, all that carbon it captured is far more likely to sink, albeit slowly, to the bottom and be sequestered.

Hey, everyone! I'm a PhD. student I'm animal science. I spent my masters project (i.e., the last 2 years) studying the environmental impact of beef cattle, particularly methane. What Hank said about agriculture is generally correct; however, with most things, the real answer is more complicated. Cattle do produce methane, which is does trap more heat than carbon dioxide, but methane has a half life of about 12 years as opposed to carbon dioxide's half life of hundreds of years. If anyone has questions about some of the steps the beef industry is taking to reduce their climate impact, I'd be happy to share what I know!

No one likes this, but cattle can also be fitted with tanks to capture the methane to be used as fuel. When used in place of fossil fuels, methane not only produces far less carbon, but also ceases to be methane, which is itself a greenhouse gas far worse than Carbon dioxide. This system has already been put into place by some ranches in Oregon and in South America. I'm not saying this will solve the problem by a longshot. There need not be a magic pill that solves all of these problems at once, but rather a lot of tiny solutions that add up.
